findings.finding_description: People are more likely to say a side-effect was brought about intentionally when it is harmful than when it is helpful.
findings.hypothesis: A person’s intuitions as to whether or not a given side-effect was produced 'intentionally' can be influenced by that person’s attitude toward the specific side-effect in question (specifically whether it is good or bad).

findings.finding_description: There is an asymmetry in the assignment of praise and blame for side-effects, where agents receive more blame for bad side-effects than praise for good ones.
findings.hypothesis: People are considerably more willing to blame the agent for bad side-effects than to praise the agent for good side-effects.

sub_studies.content: Participants read a story about a chairman implementing a program to increase profits, with a known environmental side-effect (harming or helping) that the chairman claims not to care about.

items.question_text: How much blame the chairman deserved for what he did (harm condition) / how much praise the chairman deserved (help condition)
items.context: Assessing moral responsibility for the side-effect.

items.question_text: Did the chairman intentionally harm/help the environment?

participants.demographics: People spending time in a Manhattan public park.
participants.group_assignments: Randomly assigned to either the 'harm condition' or the 'help condition'.

statistical_results.claim: The difference in intentionality judgments between the harm and help conditions was highly statistically significant.
Overall, subjects said that the agent deserved a lot of blame in the harm condition but very little praise in the help condition.

findings.finding_description: The asymmetry in intentionality judgments persists in a military context, independent of corporate-specific perceptions.
findings.hypothesis: The effect observed in Experiment 1 is general and not specific to corporations or environmental damage.

findings.finding_description: The assignment of praise/blame is correlated with intentionality judgments.
findings.hypothesis: The asymmetry in praise and blame assignment may be at the root of the asymmetry in the application of the concept intentional.

items.question_text: How much blame the lieutenant deserved for what he did (harm condition) / how much praise the lieutenant deserved (help condition)
items.context: Assessing moral responsibility for the side-effect.

The total amount of praise or blame that subjects offered was correlated with their judgements about whether or not the side-effect was brought about intentionally.

paper_title: Intentional Action and Side-Effects in Ordinary Language
paper_abstract: The paper addresses a controversy in the concept of intentional action: whether side-effects of an action are brought about intentionally. The author hypothesizes that people's intuitions are influenced by their attitude toward the specific side-effect. Through two experiments, the author demonstrates an asymmetry: people are considerably more willing to say a side-effect was brought about intentionally when they regard that side-effect as bad (harmful) than when they regard it as good (helpful). This finding suggests that the assignment of praise and blame is at the root of how people apply the concept of intentionality.
